entry.title: Boost Sales Efficiency with SAP Sales Cloud v2 Territory Management – Join Our Pilot!
entry.content:
Are you looking to enhance your sales efficiency by ensuring accurate account management while preventing coverage gaps and double ownership? If so, we have good news for you!

SAP Enterprise Support is excited to announce a new pilot offering designed to help your organization master Territory Management in SAP Sales Cloud, Version 2.

About the Pilot

The “Territory Management for Sales Employees and Administrators in SAP Sales Cloud, Version 2” pilot is an expert-guided implementation workstream that empowers customers to design, configure, and test an effective Territory Management model. Over two days, participants will gain:

  • Strategic clarity on how to structure and manage sales territories effectively
  • Technical readiness to implement and operate Territory Management within SAP Sales Cloud v2
  • Hands-on experience using their own test tenant with existing master data

This service targets both sales employees and administrators responsible for territory setup and maintenance, ensuring a seamless transition to effective territory alignment.

Who Should Participate?

This pilot is ideal for organizations that:

  • Hold a valid SAP Sales Cloud v2 license.
  • Have access to a test tenant of SAP Sales Cloud v2.
  • Maintain essential master data in the test tenant, including:
    • Accounts
    • Business users and employees
    • Sales account teams
    • Sales employee responsibilities
    • Sales territory owners
    • Opportunities
      Optionally leads, quotes, and sales orders
  • Are ready to implement the workshop learnings in their own environment post-session.

Ready to Pilot and Transform Your Sales Organization?

If your organization meets the criteria above, don’t miss this opportunity to join a new pilot service designed to maximize your investment in SAP Sales Cloud Territory Management.

Reach out today to the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council for detailed information and take the first step toward a streamlined, efficient sales coverage model.

We look forward to partnering with you on this exciting journey to better sales performance.

More information: short video here

Get Involved? Be part of the innovation!

  • Visit ESAC on SAP Support Portal (please note this page will be updated soon with this new workstream)
  • contact us:  esac@sap.com

entry.title: Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond
entry.content:
Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond

The role of Application Management Services (AMS) in SAP environments is changing faster than ever. With enterprises accelerating S/4HANA adoption, cloud modernization, and digital transformation, traditional AMS models built around ticketing and reactive support are no longer sufficient. The next generation of AMS must be predictive, intelligent, automation-driven, and closely aligned with business outcomes.

With over 18 years of SAP Basis and AMS leadership experience, I have witnessed how AMS delivery must evolve to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. This article outlines a future-ready SAP AMS framework that integrates digital capabilities, cloud operations, AI, and business value alignment.

  1. From Reactive Support to Predictive Operations

Traditional AMS focused on resolving incidents as they came in.
Future AMS is built on:

  • Predictive and proactive monitoring
  • Real-time alerting
  • Automated diagnostics
  • Automated remediation for recurring issues
  • Pattern-based problem identification
  • Preventive maintenance based on system behavior

By transitioning to predictive AMS, organizations significantly reduce system downtime and improve operational stability.

  1. Intelligent Automation as the Core AMS Engine

Automation is fundamental to modern AMS transformation. A layered automation strategy strengthens efficiency across all support levels:

L1 Automation

  • User unlocks
  • Password resets
  • System checks
  • Basic monitoring alerts

L2 Automation

  • Transport automation
  • Database checks
  • Log analysis
  • Kernel and patch validations

 L3 Automation

  • Automated corrective scripts
  • RCA-based remediation
  • Performance optimization
  • DR validation routines

In large enterprise environments, such structured automation can reduce incident resolution time by 25-40%, enabling teams to focus on continuous improvement.

  1. Cloud-Optimized AMS for Hybrid & Multi-Cloud Environments

As organizations adopt AWS, Azure, GCP, and private cloud, AMS must include:

  • Cloud-native monitoring & observability
  • Automated scaling and resource optimization
  • Integration with SAP Cloud ALM
  • Hybrid security and connectivity
  • Cost governance and cloud financial operations
  • Blueprinting for cloud-based DR & HA

Future-proof AMS requires deep alignment with cloud-first operating models.

  1. Continuous Readiness Using SAP Activate Principles

SAP Activate is no longer just an implementation methodology, its structure can elevate AMS delivery as well.

AMS teams benefit from adopting:

  • Fit-to-standard for support process optimization
  • Sprint-based enhancements
  • Continuous testing automation
  • Controlled deployment cycles
  • Better documentation lifecycle governance

This ensures agility, transparency, and predictable quality across AMS operations.

  1. Business Value Alignment: Beyond SLA-Based AMS

Traditional AMS KPIs measured:

  • Ticket closure rates
  • SLA compliance
  • Response/resolution times

Modern AMS must move towards business-centric KPIs, such as:

  • Reduction in operational costs
  • Process cycle time improvements
  • Lower number of business disruptions
  • Acceleration of month-end closing
  • Enhanced performance of critical transactions
  • User productivity metrics

A future-proof AMS model is measured not by the number of tickets, but by how much business value it creates.

  1. Strengthening AMS with DR, HA & Cyber Resilience

With rising cyber threats and compliance needs, AMS teams must embed resilience into daily operations:

  • DR drills (automated where possible)
  • High availability validations
  • Security vulnerability management
  • Backup lifecycle automation
  • User access risk reviews
  • Zero Trust-based controls

Cyber-resilient AMS ensures business continuity in a world of increasing system risks.

  1. Building the AMS Workforce of the Future

SAP AMS roles are evolving. Successful teams now require hybrid skills across:

Technical Skills

  • SAP Basis + Cloud + Security
  • S/4HANA architecture
  • Integration (APIs, middleware)

Functional Skills

  • End-to-end process knowledge
  • Analytical and problem-solving abilities

Digital Skills

  • Automation scripting
  • AI/ML-based monitoring
  • Observability tools

The AMS workforce of 2025 is cross-skilled, automation-first, and business-oriented.

Conclusion

SAP AMS is shifting from a reactive support function to a strategic enabler of digital transformation. Organizations that adopt intelligent automation, cloud-ready operations, strong governance models, and business-aligned KPIs will achieve:

  • Higher stability
  • Lower operational costs
  • Faster innovation
  • Better user experience
  • Stronger digital outcomes

The future of AMS is not about keeping systems running ,it’s about creating continuous business value.

Thank You for Reading

Feel free to share your thoughts or your organization’s AMS transformation experiences in the comments. I look forward to engaging with the SAP Community and contributing more insights on SAP delivery, operations, and digital transformation.

entry.title: Re: Verboten?
entry.content:
Hello,

There are some SAP Notes that are intended to be available for a specific group of S-user only. There are many different reasons, like not officially released content that must have agreement, under test, etc.

It is not expected to have those SAP Notes available through the search tools. So, if you receive it from other channels than SAP development or technical support, this can be the reason for the lack of access.

Regards.

entry.title: What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management 2511
entry.content:
This November release is a bumper edition and the most significant of the year for SAP Asset Performance Management. It brings Embedded IoT out of early adopter access into general availability, introduces new CAP applications, opening exciting extensibility possibilities for asset management. And there are great enhancements for rules, industrial systems and recommendations. Here's an overview:

  • Embedded IoT is now available to all customers and partner
  • Managing Industrial Systems and Industrial System Templates Just Got Easier
  • New CAP Applications for Risk & Criticality Applications
  • Assign monitoring rules directly to proactive recommendations with the Condition subtype.
  • Copy standalone recommendations from both the object and list pages.
  • Navigate directly to maintenance plans or task lists in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.
  • Improvements to Rule Processing
    • Cleaner Data: Automatic Exclusion of Obsolete Technical Objects
    • Automatic Rule Triggering for New Measurement Data
  • Extensibility and Performance Improvements
  • Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

Embedded IoT is now available to all customers and partners!!

The centerpiece of this release is the general availability of Embedded IoT. Previously available only to early adopters, Embedded IoT now allows organizations to bring IoT device management and condition monitoring fully into SAP Asset Performance Management.

The launchpad of SAP Asset Performance Management now contains 5 new application tiles that are accessible to end-users depending on their assigned business roles. These tiles navigate directly to the respective applications in the IoT platform:

You can:

  • Manage Devices – Onboard, configure, and control IoT devices across their lifecycle.
  • Map Devices to Technical Objects – Link devices to the assets they monitor for seamless integration.
  • Manage Streaming Rules – Process IoT data at the individual data point level in near real-time.
  • Manage IoT Dashboards – Central workspace for monitoring devices and visualizing insights.

IoT Platform Administration – Configure the platform, manage users, and control system-wide settings.

This brings true end-to-end asset monitoring into the hands of asset managers, with near real-time insights, automated rule triggering, and integrated dashboards for decision-making. For more information and videos, see the dedicated blog by Florian Weigold Embedded IoT is here: 5 apps that accelerate sensor to insight in SAP Asset Performance Management.

Managing Industrial Systems and Industrial System Templates Just Got Easier

See how the new 2511 features make a reliability engineer’s day smoother and more efficient.

Template Work: Reviewing and Updating

Your first job is to review an Industrial System Template with hundreds of elements. You open the Structure tab expecting the usual lag... but now, the Structure tab opens instantly in a new default table view for hierarchies with over three hundred elements providing a much better performance. A good start to the day! For more information, see Components of Industrial System Template Structure.

Soon after, a colleague asks who changed part of the template last week. With the new Change Logs , you find and export the full history in seconds. For more information, see View and Export Change Logs. Later, you want to make an update to the template, which is already released - something that wasn't possible before, now  - and even push the changes to all connected systems. 
A quick glance at the newly introduced Reference Designator Library Version in the table view confirms everything is aligned. 

By the end of the template review, you’ve worked faster, avoided workarounds, and ensured all templates are accurate and up to date.

Industrial System Work: Monitoring and Troubleshooting

After lunch, you move on to Industrial Systems. You create a new industrial system from a template: the structure stays fixed, while product aspects, descriptions, and organisational attributes remain editable. The new Synchronization Status instantly shows it’s up to date with the template.

Shortly after a technician calls: they need to take a pump sub-assembly offline for a quick check.
Before, you had to improvise workarounds. Now, you just deactivate the system element with one click. Once the check is complete, you reactivate it just as easily. For more information, see Activate or Deactivate a System Element.. 

Before you leave for the day you check the change logs for yesterday’s update — the pressure sensor mappings on Compressor 3 were adjusted in the control system during night shift, and you can see exactly who changed what and when.

Two minutes later, a colleague pings you “Can you check Compressor 3? The output readings don’t seem right.” You open the system’s structure — enormous with over three hundred interconnected elements that used to freeze your screen — but today, just like the template, it loads instantly in the optimized table view, so you can spot the mismatch immediately.

While you’re there, you quickly verify the reference designator library version to ensure the system is aligned with the latest engineering release. Everything matches.  You also check the Organizational Attributes in the system’s Excel export to confirm that ownership and responsibilities are up to date. For more information see Creating an Industrial System from Excel and Export or Import Sytem Structure

Thanks to the recent API migration from the Asset Health package to the Manage Asset Data package, your scripts and integrations run smoothly without any hiccups. For more information, refer to Manage Asset Data API

By the end of the day, you've worked faster, with more clarity and fewer workarounds — thanks to thoughtful enhancements across both templates and systems.

In a nutshell:

  • Industrial systems and templates can now display reference designator library versions, track change logs, and synchronize with templates for better alignment.
  • Large system hierarchies default to table view for faster navigation, improving usability in complex environments.
  • Released templates can be edited and changes pushed to associated systems, giving teams more flexibility to evolve structures without losing control.
  • System elements can now be activated or deactivated, and limited edits to systems created from templates are supported.
  • Together, these improvements make the platform more responsive, adaptable, and ready for advanced use cases.

We will be releasing a dedicated blog on industrial systems and template next week. Watch this space.

New CAP Applications for Risk & Criticality Applications

With the 2511 release, we’re introducing two new CAP-based applications: Manage Templates for Risk & Criticality Assessments and Manage Risk & Criticality Assessments. These CAP apps bring a more modern, scalable, and extensible architecture, delivering smoother performance and a more consistent user experience. 

You can enable the new CAP-based apps by adding the new authorization scope (RiskCriticality_CAP) to the users. Watch this space for a dedicated blog in the coming weeks.

For more information on release timelines, implementation, support, and known limitations, refer to SAP Note 3603407

Entry Point to New CAP-Based Applications for Risk and Criticality on SAP Fiori Launchpad

 Asset Reliability Engineering

Recommendations have become even more actionable:

Assign monitoring rules directly to proactive recommendations with the Condition subtype.

With the 2511 release, APM restores an important capability: assigning IoT monitoring rules to proactive condition-based recommendations. This was available in the earlier SAP IoT solution, but the new embedded IoT version delivers it on a stronger and more modern foundation - a more powerful rules application and a new, independent dataset application.

This evolved architecture makes the connection between IoT rules and APM recommendations cleaner, more flexible, and easier to extend than it was in sIoT. Instead of simply copying the old behaviour, APM now integrates with IoT rules in a way that matches the newer, more capable platform.

What problem are we solving?

Before the ability to assign eIoT monitoring rules, proactive condition-based recommendations were largely static. Maintenance teams could see a recommendation, but there was no automated way to know when it actually needed attention. Decisions about timing relied on manual monitoring, scheduled inspections, or guesswork, which could lead to reactive maintenance, unnecessary work, or missed opportunities to prevent failures. Recommendations lacked the proper context from real-time sensor data, making it difficult to prioritize actions effectively or ensure maintenance was truly condition-driven.

The new CAP recommendation app now includes a dedicated section for assigning embedded IoT monitoring rules. Once a rule is linked, APM can automatically react when that rule detects an unusual pattern in the sensor data.

Currently you cannot create rules directly in the app, only assign them. Rules - and their associated datasets — must be created separately in the their own applications.

Watch this quick demo:

Video demo showing how to assign monitoring rules to proactive condition-based recommendations in the new CAP-based Implement Recommendations app

UI improvements

Information for rules is now in the recommendation column of the Implement Recommendations list page. You can click on the rule(s) associated with the recommendation and see a popup, from where you can navigate directly to the Manage Rules and Manage Datasets apps.

UI enhancements for rules in the Implement Recommendations app

Copy standalone recommendations from both the object and list pages.

You can now copy a standalone recommendation with and without coding mask from both the object page and the list page in the Manage Recommendations app.

In many reliability and maintenance processes, teams often create multiple recommendations that are nearly identical, especially when working across similar assets, recurring failure modes, or repeated strategy decisions. Until now, every recommendation had to be created manually from scratch, even when most of the content already existed elsewhere.

The new Copy Recommendation function solves this problem. You take an existing standalone recommendation and create a new one with the same core information already prefilled. This includes the recommendation details and notes, but intentionally not the comments—because comments usually reflect a specific discussion on the original recommendation and shouldn’t be carried forward.

The copied recommendation is treated as a new object with no linkage or lineage to the source—just a convenient head start.

Business Value

  • Speed: Reduces effort when creating multiple similar recommendations.

  • Consistency: Ensures repeated recommendations follow the same structure and information.

  • Quality: Minimises manual entry errors by reusing accurate, validated data.

  • Scalability: Particularly valuable during large strategy projects, where dozens or hundreds of recommendations need to be generated efficiently.

For more information, refer to Copying a Recommendation.

Example: Copy recommendation with coding mask in Manage Recommendations app

Navigate directly to maintenance plans or task lists in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

To make maintenance workflows more efficient, we added direct navigation from recommendations to the related Task List or Maintenance Plan. Customers can configure the Launchpad URL for their environment, and the system generates links that open the correct object in the corresponding application.

This eliminates the need to search manually, saving time and reducing errors. Teams can move seamlessly from identifying an issue to implementing the required actions, improving efficiency and traceability across large maintenance projects.

To navigate to SAP S/4HANA system to view maintenance list details, you have configured the destination information in the BTP cockpit. For more information, see Creating a Maintenance Plan for Recommendation and Creating a Task List for Recommendation.

 

Improvements to Rule Processing

We have introduced two improvements to enhance the accuracy and automation of rule-based monitoring across SAP Asset Performance Management.

What Problem Are We Solving?

Until now, aggregation rules could be affected by irrelevant technical objects (for example, objects already inactive or marked for deletion) and sometimes required manual intervention to trigger rule execution when new measurement data arrived. This led to inconsistent results, unnecessary noise in aggregated values, and additional effort for reliability engineers.

What’s New

Cleaner Data: Automatic Exclusion of Obsolete Technical Objects

When creating aggregation rules, child technical objects with the statuses  Inactive, Marked for Deletion, or Deleted are now automatically excluded.  This ensures that only valid and active parts of your asset structure contribute to aggregated calculations, resulting in more accurate monitoring and fewer irrelevant results. For more information, see Creating an Aggregation Rule.

Automatic Rule Triggering for New Measurement Data

Rules using the Measurement Document Ingestion trigger now run automatically when:

  • A measurement document is replicated from SAP S/4HANA
  • A new indicator value is created manually

This eliminates manual steps, ensures rules react immediately to fresh data, and helps reliability engineers maintain up-to-date insights without intervention. For more information, see Triggering a Rule.

 

Rule creation will follow in a future release, but rule assignment is already fully supported — bringing condition-based maintenance back with a more modern and future-ready design.

For more information, refer to Implementing a Proactive Type Condition Recommendation.

Extensibility and Performance Improvements

With the new CAP applications, this also opens the door to greater extensibility, allowing organizations to adapt applications and processes to their unique needs. Watch this space for a dedicated blog on how to configure the CAP apps to enable extensibility. Coming soon!

Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Private Edition

The 2025 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition brings deeper integration with SAP Asset Performance Management (APM). APM recommendations, indicators, and assessments are now visible directly in the Find Technical Objects app, together with risk and criticality information. In addition, APM failure data relationships can now be used to select Failure Modes and Failure Effects during maintenance processes, ensuring the right task lists are assigned and actions are aligned with historical recommendations.

For full details, read Fernanda Rodrigues' blog Asset Management in SAP Cloud ERP Private 2025 Release and explore Fernanda's other blogs too.

Stay Informed and Get Involved

  • Find out what's up and coming in the SAP Road Map Explorer.
  • For an exhaustive list of all new features, visit the SAP Help Portal - What's New in SAP Asset Performance Management.. 
  • Send us your improvement requests. Submit or vote for the improvement you would like to see in the SAP Continuous Influence session.
  • Check the APM link collection. 

Let us know what you think about these new features - leave us a comment below or ask a question! 

See you soon for the 2512 update!

entry.title: SAP Hands-on Workshop: SAP Signavio BPM
entry.content:
¡Inscríbete aquí!

Duración: 4 horas

Fecha: 12 de diciembre

Descripción:  SAP Signavio se ha consolidado como una de las principales herramientas a nivel global para modelar, optimizar y gestionar procesos de negocio de manera colaborativa. En el contexto de la transformación digital actual, la gestión de procesos es esencial para aumentar la eficiencia, calidad y agilidad en las organizaciones. Este hands-on busca cerrar la brecha entre el conocimiento teórico de BPM y la capacidad práctica para diseñar procesos bajo estándares profesionales.

Como parte de la Iniciativa Académica de SAP Signavio BPM, los participantes—compuestos por profesores y estudiantes—aprenderán a navegar y utilizar el SAP Signavio Process Collaboration Hub y a modelar procesos utilizando BPMN 2.0. No se requiere experiencia previa con SAP Signavio, ya que el hands-on ofrece una experiencia práctica y directa.

Dirigido por Alfredo Armijos De La Cruz, con una vasta experiencia en gestión de proyectos y transformación empresarial, el taller abarcará desde la introducción a los conceptos fundamentales de BPM hasta el desarrollo en modelado práctico con casos reales. La aprobación se basará en la realización de quizzes y la práctica guiada dentro de la plataforma SAP Signavio Process Manager.

Hora de inicio: 09:00 AM (UTC-5)

Hora de finalización: 01:00 PM (UTC-5)

¡Bueno saberlo!

  • ¡La inscripción es GRATUITA! 
  • Por favor, tenga en cuenta que no habrá una respuesta perfecta para cada pregunta/sección para todos los datos requeridos en el proceso de registro, ya que el sitio web/la tecnología que utilizamos es un sitio web de eventos universal de SAP. Le pedimos amablemente que elija la opción que mejor se adapte a usted.
  • Recomendamos seleccionar "Higher Education & Research" en el campo "Industry", "Partner" en el campo "Relationship with SAP" y "Delegate" en el campo "Function". La opción que elija no influirá en el estado de su registro.
  • Para completar tu registro, es necesario usar un correo académico o uno vinculado a una universidad.

    No dude en contactarnos con cualquier pregunta a través de Universityalliances@sap.com.


¡Inscríbete aquí!

entry.title: Workshop Hands-On: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) para profesores y estudiantes
entry.content:
El próximo 5 de diciembre, viernes, no se pierdan el emocionante workshop de SAP Analytics Cloud, un taller práctico de 4 horas que les permitirá explorar y aprovechar al máximo las capacidades de esta poderosa herramienta de análisis de datos.

¿Qué es SAP Analytics Cloud?

SAP Analytics Cloud es una solución integral de análisis de datos que permite a las empresas tomar decisiones basadas en datos en tiempo real. Con sus capacidades avanzadas de visualización de datos, análisis predictivo y planificación, SAP Analytics Cloud proporciona a los usuarios una visión profunda y detallada de sus datos, ayudándoles a identificar tendencias, oportunidades y desafíos comerciales.

¿Por qué asistir?

Este workshop, ministrado por Marcela Revilla, Senior SAP Consultant Instructor, está diseñado para ofrecerles una experiencia completa y enriquecedora. Marcela, con su amplia experiencia en integración de procesos de negocio y configuración de sistemas, les guiará a través de aulas teóricas y ejercicios prácticos, asegurando que adquieran habilidades valiosas que pueden aplicar inmediatamente en su trabajo.

Detalles del Workshop

  • Fecha: 5 de diciembre, viernes
  • Duración: 4 horas
  • Instructor: Marcela Revilla, Senior SAP Consultant Instructor
  • Certificación: Todos los participantes recibirán un certificado de participación al finalizar el taller.

Inscripción: SAP SAC Workshop 2025

Recuerden que para realizar su inscripción, es necesario registrarse con un correo electrónico académico o el correo electrónico vinculado a su universidad. Asegúrense de proporcionar sus datos de contacto para recibir toda la información necesaria sobre el evento, incluyendo el enlace de acceso y cualquier material preparatorio.

entry.title: CM25 - Extended planning table: Incorrect column headers
entry.content:
Hello experts,

When executing transaction CM25 and using the extended planning function for user, the 'Period requirements per resource' table that's displayed shows incorrect column headers. These headers should reference either a date or an abbreviation of a weekday. But instead, it shows as follows:

 The columns headers are displayed as an abreviation of the day that the table is obtained. When executed on a friday, the columns are displayed as "VI", short for VIernes, in Spanish. Instead, it should display the planning period, in this case, weekdays, e.g: LU, MA, MI, JU & VI.

Are there any SAP Notes related to this issue? customizing paths to review? any table I should look up to?Thoughts on how to proceed?

Your help will be highly appreciated,

Thanks in advance,

Sebastián

entry.title: S/4HANA 2023 FPS3 Fully-Activated Appliance standard installation
entry.content:
This blog covers installation of (1) SAP S/4HANA server and (2) SAP NW JAVA / ADS server as shown in the graphic below. The installation is based on file restore and is different from the standard installs using SWPM.

Please refer to S/4HANA SQUARE ONE for other blogs

In this blog the procedure is simplified for standard installation with NO HOSTNAME OR SID CHANGE. The advantage with this is that you don't have to do many of the steps related to SID change and it does make sense if you will be installing the instance temporarily. If your network cannot accommodate the unique hostname and SID and If you want to change hostname and sid please refer to other  blog (TBD). Also if it is a more permanent installation you may like to change SID and hostname.

This Blog is based on a fresh installation of SUSE Linux for SAP OS without having any previous SAP instances created and deleted. I did not have to pre install hostagent, etc. There are mount points/links to be setup as shown in the right place in the directory structure. The steps in the guides provided with SAP Note 2041140 could be used as a reference in case there are issues specific to your environment. Just follow the steps below to install both systems shown in red square below:

Please find below the main note for ordering the appliance:
2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

PART1: SOFTWARE DOWNLOAD

Please download the software media from https://me.sap.com/softwarecenter
INSTALLATIONS & UPGRADES => By Alphabetical Index (A-Z) => S => SAP S/4HANA => SAP S/4HANA 2023 => S/4HANA FULLY-ACTIVATED APPLIANCE => SAP S/4HANA 2023 FPS03 FA APPL

On SAP S/4HANA Server, download the 51058694_1 to 51058694_5  files and SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SAR (or later).

On SAP NW JAVA / ADS server, download the 51058694_5, SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR and 51050829_JAVA_part 1 & 2 - NW 7.5 Java based SW Comp.

PART2: INSTALL SAP S/4HANA

STEP 1: PREPARE SYSTEM Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. For /sapmnt provide min 30GB, /hana/data space - min 500GB, /hana/log min 120GB. I have used /sapmedia - 200GB temporary separate mount that can be removed later.

TIP: The /sapmedia filesystem could be external mount. To save this space, the files could be downloaded to /hana/data/HDB and deleted as they are being extracted. In this case it would be good to extract dbdata files first.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: EXTRACT FILES Extract files 51058694_*  in /sapmedia

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_1.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_2.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_3.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_4.ZIP
sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

Allow approx 2 hours for extraction.

We will install Central system with DB and App on same server. Please move all *.tgz-* files (from 51058694_1 to 51058694_4) to /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1

cd /sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
mv /sapmedia/51058694_2/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_2/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_3/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_3/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_4/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_4/*.tgz-*   .
mv /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_5/*.tgz-*   .

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

Please use command below to extract the database related archives:

sid-hdb-s4h:/sapmedia/# cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

Similarly extract the remaining files:

cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

It takes about an hour for extraction.

Below two Application related archives may be extracted on a separate app server for distributed installation. These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/S4H and /usr/sap/S4H

Then extract the files:
sid-hdb-s4h:/usr/sap #cd 51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2023FPS03SAPHANADB20_1
cat sapmnt.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
cat usrsap.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: GET PASSWORDS Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_1/SAPS4HANA2022FPS01SAPHANADB20_1/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE 

Follow this procedure as it is a known issue, please refer SAP Note 2082466 - Known Issues in SAP HANA Platform Lifecycle Management (HDBLCM)  (Issue# 69)

cd /hana/shared/HDB/HDB02/vhcalhdbdb
rm .daemon.ini.swp

vi daemon.ini
Edit section [localsecurestore] to change instances = 0

Execute HANA database specific steps as below:

sid-hdb-s4h: ##/hana/shared/HDB/hdblcm/hdblcm --action=register_rename_system

This should bring up the database processes as below

sid-hdb-s4h: #/usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 02 -function GetProcessList

STEP 5: EXTRACT SWPM Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install ##/sapmnt/S4H/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM20SP22_3-80003424.SA

STEP 6:RENAME SAP SYSTEM Rename instance using sapinst, although we want to keep SID same as standard - S4H we need to run the procedure so that the process installs the missing items.

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcals4hci SAPINST_SLP_MODE=false

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-hdb-s4h.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST above screen select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At above screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System S4H and Target System S4H:
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Connectivity enter Instance Number 02 and Password Welcome_2Welocme_2. Click on Next.

At the screen SAP HANA Database Parameter you can change Schema User , DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM password. Please note it is also optional to change the schema user SAPHANADB password along with DBACOCKPIT and SYSTEM users.

At the screen Database Schema accept schema SAPHANADB password and confirm Schema password Xxxxxxxn click on Next.

At the screen Rename Tenant Database click on Next

At the screen Secure Storage for Database Connection select HANA Secure User tore (hdbuserstore) click on Next

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Secure Storage Key Generation accept radio button – Individual Key (Recommended for Productive Systems) On the Next

At next screen Warning click OK

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next

At the above screen Keep Existing Licenses accept unchecked of Keep existing licenses. Click on Next

At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.
At next screen Cleanup of Encryption key checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next
Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

TIP: In case you get this ERROR:

RESOLUTION: Follow SAP Note 2800204 - SSFX-0362: Value file "-" does not start with the UTF-8 byte order mark

Ensure the environment variable LC_CTYPE of the user running sapinst is set as LC_CTYPE=en_US.
Stop the current sapinst and restart it. Continue with the existing option.

Then you can manually start the SAP instance S4H

sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 01 -function StartSystem ALL
sid-hdb-s4h:/install # /usr/sap/hostctrl/exe/sapcontrol -nr 00 -function StartSystem ALL

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder and remove temporary links to S4H.

Standard users are as follows:
HANA DB – Instance 02 SYSTEM /<Master Password>
Web Dispatcher access : bpinst/Welcome_2Welcome_2

STEP 7: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf => Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Adapt HANA connections in DBACOCKPIT

Host name / port in table HTTPURLLOC

Adapt RFC Connections if needed

ABAP connections:
• LOCAL_RFC
• S4HCLNT100 (and other clients)
• S4H_RFC

HTTP connections:
• ADS (pointing to the JAVA server after PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA /ADS)
• LOCAL_HTTP
• LOCAL_HTTPS
• S4FIN_HTTPS

SAP Enable Now Web Assistant

Adapt the Fiori notification URL

Adapt Enterprise Search

Apply product license keys

Install software product license key: Technical restrictions may apply if you don’t install the license. Use the link to obtain license key.
HANA DB license key can be installed via HANA Studio (Preferences -> License)
From SAP S/4HANA 1909 onwards the license key is installed via SAP logon tCode SLICENSE

Further post-installation checks

Install SAP client tools on your local computers

You can take a full backup and remove the temporary links that were setup for S4H

In client 000 fix transport configuration. Enter tCode SE06 and reinstall CTS transport system.

Adapt any SAP parameters required

The database is provided with log mode overwrite and you may like to change that as needed.

PART3: INSTALL SAP NW JAVA / ADS

STEP 1: Prepare Linux Server as below for the appliance. The values in Used column below show the minimum size needed. Total filesystem needed is min 70GB for installation.

The /etc/hostname and /etc/host file is below:

STEP 2: Extract files 51058694_5.ZIP  in /sapmedia

sid-j2e:/sapmedia# unzip 51058694_5.ZIP

We will install Java instance from files in  /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

cd /sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices

In the next step we will extract the above *.tgz files but please note the directories size is as follows so you can provide ample space:

These files will be extracted under /sapmnt/J2E

sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dblog.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dbexe.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat dbdata.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat sapmnt_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /
sid-j2e:/sapmedia# cat usrsap_j2e.tgz-* | tar -zpxvf - -C /

STEP 3: Download the file below and open the file in Internet Explorer to note passwords:
/sapmedia/51058694_5/SAPNetWeaver750SP31ASJAVAwithAdobeDocumentServices/SAP_Software_Appliance.xml

STEP 4: Extract SWPM in folder /install. Use the SAPCAR already available to extract.

sid-j2e:/install #/sapmnt/J2E/exe/uc/linuxx86_64/SAPCAR -xvf /sapmedia/SWPM10SP45_2-20009701.SAR

STEP 5: Rename instance using sapinst

sid-j2e:/install # ./sapinst SAPINST_ENFORCE_CRL=false SAPINST_USE_HOSTNAME=vhcalj2eci SAPINST_SLP_MODE=false

Copy below URL into chrome browser to start sapinst rename process:

https://sid-j2e.dummy.nodomain:4237/sapinst/docs/index.html

In SAPINST select System Rename => Standard System => SAP System Rename

At the screen Software Integrity click on Next

At screen SAP System Parameters enter Source System J2E
Click on Next.

At the screen Prerequisite Checker Results accept or fix the Prerequisite check results.
Click on Next. No if you don't want to repeat the test

At the screen SAP Instance Parameters accept or change the Target System Instance Numbers.
Click on Next.

At the screen Database System Type keep the default selection SAP Adaptive Server Enterprise for Business Suite

At the screen Operating System Users accept master password or enter password Xxxxxxxn

At the screen Operating System User for SAP Database Administrator enter the password for sybj2e and User ID and Click on Next

At the screen SAP ASE Database System Parameters accept or change ports and Click on Next

At the screen Database User Passwords enter the passwords for user sa, sapsa, sapsso, SAPSR3DB which is Welcome_2Welcome_2. Click on Next

At the screen DNS Domain Name checkmark Set FQDN for SAP System and enter domain name dummy.nodomain Click on Next
At the screen Install License Key keep unchecked Install License Key. Click on Next

TIP: It is much easier to install the license by providing the file than doing it later through the application.

At next screen Cleanup of Operating System Users checkmark on Yes cleanup os users and click on Next

Here is the Parameter Summary Click on Next to confirm and begin the installation.

 

You can manually start/stop the SAP Java instance J2E using old commands

sid-j2e:/install # su - j2eadm
sid-j2e:j2eadm > startsap

To access JAVA server as SAP Netweaver Adminstrator the URL is:
https://sid-j2e.dummy.nodomain:50000/nwa

Standard users are as follows:

JAVA Administrator – Administrator / <Master Password> ;
Java user BPINST/Welcome2Welcome2

STEP 6: Follow steps from guide attached to SAP Note 2041140 - First Steps for on-premise installations.pdf - Section 5 Technical Post-deployment Activities

Apply product license keys if you haven't installed during swpm install step before. Technical restrictions may apply if you don’t install the license. Use the link to obtain license key. SAPNetweaver 7.5 J2EE license key has to be installed via SAP Netweaver Administrator

Further post-installation checks

Adapt any SAP parameters due to changed SID

After instance is started and confirmed you can delete the sapmedia folder.

SUPPORT TICKETS:

If you have any difficulty downloading the media open OSS message using component XX-SER-SAPSMP-SWC. If you have issues with technical deployment open message with component BC-INS-SRN.

OTHER REFERENCES:

SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Create your SAP S/4HANA system in a fraction of the usual setup time
SAP S/4HANA Fully-Activated Appliance: Demo Guides

Blogs with known issues (2022 / 2021 / 2020), continuously updated

2041140 - Order an SAP pre-assembled Best Practices software appliance (as partner or customer)

Thank you. Hope you enjoyed the installation.

Mahesh Sardesai
Product Expert – S/4HANA

entry.title: Re: Add Material Description and Partner Activity Type Fi...
entry.content:
Hello @Alendro17 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Data Source Extensions, Key User Extensibility, Market Segment - Plan/Actuals, Projects - Plan/Actual

I would also recommend reading through Blogs: Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud – Data Source Extensions – Part 1 & Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud – Data Source Extensions – Part 2

In summary, please note that the clean-core principle in the public cloud ensures the system provide the predefined process. Which explains why you face some of those issues.

Below are simplified reasons and what you should do.

Answer to Issue 1: The Order ID description is not wrong; the market segment cube does not store material description for orders. You can display it by creating a custom CDS join and build a custom analytical query.

Answer to Issue 2: The Partner Activity Type is missing because the Market Segment cubes does not contain this field. You can only add it that when you use a custom CDS extension and custom query.

Answer to Issue 3: The reason it does not appear is because you did not enable analytics. You should enable the Data Source Extension in Custom Fields app and then create a custom analytical query.

 

Here is step-by-step guide on how to achieve adding the custom fields.

First is to open you Custom Fields

Then select your field, enable Analytics: Data Source (Here you should enable for Analytics, OData, UI), then save and publish.

Next you should extend Analytical Cube using Custom Analytical Queries. Click Create

For the primary Data Source, use: I_ENGMNTPROJACTLPLANCUBE.

Then add your custom fields.

Thereafter, create your custom report. You can give as an example the name Z_PROJECT_PLAN_ACTUAL. Then add your fields, publish it and add it to Fiori catalog.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Use Datastore to avoid too many duplicate MPL attachments in exception retries
entry.content:
Hi,

This is a clever way to avoid storing the same payload multiple times. Thank you for this insight!

However, I'm curious—when would unlimited or very high retry limits (such as 100 attempts) be applicable? In my experience, retrying more than a few times doesn't make sense. Beyond that, it's better to route undelivered messages to a Dead Letter Queue (DLQ) and reduce the retry frequency.

On the other hand, this approach introduces another challenge: after a few hours, or especially days, your persisted data (particularly if it originates from data events) may already be obsolete. Delivering stale data to the target system could create discrepancies between the source and target. One solution might be to refresh the data via an API call when processing a retry.

I'd appreciate any thoughts or observations you might have on this!

BR

Mateusz

entry.title: How to Assign Item Category to Material While Syncing to SAP CPQ – And Why It Matters
entry.content:
When integrating SAP CPQ (Configure, Price, Quote) with SAP S/4HANA or ERP, ECC, one critical step often overlooked is assigning the Item Category to materials during synchronization. This seemingly small detail plays a major role in ensuring smooth downstream processes like Sales Orders, Solution Quotations, and Solution Orders.

What is an Item Category ?

An Item Category in SAP determines how a material behaves in a document. It controls:

  • Whether the item is relevant for pricing.
  • If it requires a delivery or billing.
  • Whether it’s a service, a configurable product, or a standard material.
  • How it integrates with BOMs or solution components.

Reference Article/Blog explaining Item Categeory & group : Link

In short, the Item Category defines the business logic for the material in transactional documents.

Why Assign Item Category During Sync to SAP CPQ?

When materials are synced from SAP ERP to SAP CPQ, they carry essential attributes like material number, description, and pricing conditions. However, without the correct Item Category, CPQ cannot:

  • Determine if the material is a physical product, service, or text item.
  • Apply correct pricing and tax rules.
  • Generate accurate solution structures for complex configurations.

This impacts the integration when below are created:

  • Sales Orders: Applies for all ERP, S/4 HANA Public & Private Cloud
  • Solution Quotations: S/4 HANA Private Cloud or On-prem versions (Sales, Service & Subscription)
  • Solution Orders: S/4 HANA Public Cloud Edition (Sales, Service & Subscription)

Integration with SAP CPQ for Material Replication

SAP CPQ provides Product RestAPI to update itemcategorygroup for Materials..

Technical Note: Updating Item Category in SAP CPQ

SAP CPQ provides a Product REST API that allows you to update the itemCategory field for products. This is useful when you need to dynamically adjust item categories after initial synchronization or based on business rules.

  • Field: itemCategory
  • Purpose: Stores the ERP item category value or a mapped equivalent.
  • Usage: Can be updated via REST API calls for products in CPQ.

Integration Considerations

The standard SAP CPQ–SAP ERP/S4 HANA integration iFlow currently uses SOAP XML for material synchronization. This means:

  • Item category values from ERP cannot be included in the SOAP payload. (Help Doc)
  • If additional updates are needed post-sync, you can leverage the REST API for CPQ to patch the itemCategory field.

Conclusion:
Assigning the right Item Category during material sync to SAP CPQ is not just a technical step—it’s a business-critical process that ensures seamless integration, accurate pricing, and smooth execution of sales and solution orders.

entry.title: Re: VOFM – Custom Routine for Packaging Instruction Deter...
entry.content:
Dear @vicentejarque,

No, in Public Cloud you can’t develop your own VOFM-style condition/formula routines for packing/packaging instruction determination.

What is supported in Public cloud is custom logic only where SAP has released a Cloud Badi implemented via the Custom Logic extensibility framework. SAP states this explicitly for VOFM successors for example in pricing custom logic is possible only for the delivered Cloud Badi, classic VOFM routines are an on-premise concept

Correct approach in Public Cloud:

1. Stay within standard condition technique for packing instruction determination (condition tables/access sequences/records) using only the fields SAP exposes in the field catalog

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/758cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/32da8359c8ee4e8b8e8c5e15cacba5aa/e78cbf53f106b44ce10000000a174cb4.html

2. You can sent to SAP request/incident to have Production Version added to the determination field catalog or to have a suitable Cloud Badi released on Customer Influence: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Article Discontinuation
entry.content:
Article Discontinuation – Business and Technical Overview

Article Discontinuation is a key step in an article’s lifecycle when the business decides that the product should no longer be carried. This decision can stem from several business scenarios, including:

Business Reasons for Article Discontinuation

  • Seasonal Fashion Items: Style cycles end and new season assortments are introduced.
  • End-of-Life Packaging Changes: Example: shifting from plastic bottles to eco-friendly recyclable packaging.
  • Model Upgrades in Electronics: Regular product refresh cycles.
  • Poor Sales Performance: Example: a slow-moving cereal brand removed by a grocery retailer.
  • Vendor Stops Supplying the Product.
  • Regulatory or Compliance Restrictions.
  • Short Shelf-Life or Expiry Constraints.
  • Assortment Rationalization / Space Optimization.
  • Product Safety Recalls.

Additionally, there are cases where an article is initially listed broadly for simplicity, but this creates technical issues later. In SAP Retail, listing is driven by general assortments, assortment modules, and listing conditions, and articles should only appear in sites belonging to their intended assortments. Incorrect assignments can cause unwanted listing propagation.

Business Impact of Incorrect Listing

  • Inaccurate stock availability displayed to store teams and online channels.
  • Unnecessary MRP proposals generated for all sites.
  • Incorrect data distributed to POS systems, causing clutter and possible cashier confusion.
  • Merchandising teams receive inaccurate assortment compliance reports.

Technical Impact

  • Unintended listing entries created in WLK1.
  • Additional footprints generated in tables such as MVKE, MARC, MBEW, etc.
  • POS outbound IDocs (WP_PLU) triggered for all sites.
  • Increased load on replenishment processing and EDI queues.
  • Incorrect inherited listing indicators in WRS1.
  • Business processes such as costing process unnecessary data, potentially affecting performance and increasing system footprint.

 Delisting vs. Discontinuation

Delisting (Removing Listing Conditions)

Delisting stops an article from being processed but does not remove the article master footprint.

Transaction codes for delisting:

  • WSP3 – Delete individual article listing conditions per distribution chain
  • WSE6 – Delete listing per assortment
  • Removing a site from an assortment using WSOA6 automatically delists all articles belonging to that site/assortment combination.

System behavior when an article is delisted:

  • Listing conditions are deleted automatically.
  • All listing entries (WLK1, WRS1, etc.) created through that assortment/module are removed.
  • The article master remains intact (MARA, MARC, MARD not deleted).
  • Existing stock remains visible and sellable.
  • MRP and procurement are blocked—no new POs/STOs will be created.
  • Sales may continue until on-hand stock reaches zero.

Article Discontinuation (Removing the Article Footprint)

To eliminate an article from the system, the process involves:

  1. Discontinuation – Sets the deletion indicator (LVORM)
  2. Archiving and Deletion – Executed via SARA (Object: MM_MATNR)

Discontinuation has far greater impact than delisting. When an article is discontinued:

  • The article master and all related data (purchasing info records, listing data, etc.) are marked for removal and eventually deleted through archiving.

Levels of Discontinuation

  • Client-wide
  • Supplier/Vendor
  • Plant/Site (includes distribution chain level)

Article Discontinuation Process in SAP Retail

  1. End listing conditions for the article using WSP3/WSE6/WSOA6.
  2. Trigger discontinuation using WRF_DIS_SEL (and monitor via WRF_DIS_MON).
  3. The discontinuation runs based on the Article Discontinuation Date—this must be after the ordering or sales block date.
  4. To run in background:
    • Deselect “Check material in full”
    • Select “Offline checks”

  1. Review the worklist in WRF_DIS_MON after job completion.
  2. If “Discontinue Immediately” is enabled and checks pass, SAP sets the deletion flag automatically.
  3. If issues exist, SAP lists them for manual resolution.
  4. Optional automated follow-up actions (e.g., transfer posting stock to a value-only article).
  5. Configuration: SPRO → Logistics General → Material Master → Retail Specific Settings → Settings for Material Discontinuation
  6. Once LVORM is set → Archive and delete via SARA (MM_MATNR).

Useful Information & Tools

Set deletion flags at Sales Org/Distribution Channel level

Use standard report RWSORT41MVKE
Key fields:

  • AUF_SAM: Explode generic material
  • P_TEST: Test mode
  • S_MATKL: Article Group
  • S_MATNR: Article
  • S_VKORG: Sales Organization
  • S_VTWEG: Distribution Channel

Mass Discontinuation for All Articles at a Site

  • Enter wildcard (*) for article in WRF_DIS_SEL
  • Enter target plant/site under Plant Data
  • Note: This selects all MARC records for that site—evaluate volume before execution.

Reset Deletion Flag

Use WSE8

Important Limitations

  • Discontinuation indicators in MARA/MARC cannot be set using BAPIs or IDocs. Only WRF_DIS_SEL supports this process.

entry.title: Recap SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025
entry.content:
SAP Inside Track Barcelona 2025: A Celebration of Community, Innovation, and Shared Knowledge.
What a journey it's been! Last November 14th, we wrapped up the 9th edition of SAP Inside Track Barcelona, and I'm still buzzing from the energy, connections, and incredible moments we shared together.

More Than Just an Event

There's something truly special about SAP Inside Track. Yes, it's about SAP technologies, innovation, and learning — but at its core, it's about people. It's about creating a space where developers, consultants, architects, and SAP enthusiasts can come together, share their experiences, and build genuine connections that go beyond the professional realm.
This year, we brought together +100 passionate individuals in a historic Modernist building in the heart of Barcelona. From the moment the doors opened until the last photo was taken the spirit of community was palpable.


Knowledge That Inspires

The quality of sessions this year was outstanding. Our speakers delivered thought-provoking presentations covering the full spectrum of SAP technologies:

  • AI and Innovation: From Vision AI applications in quality management to conversational AI solutions that let you "talk" to your data
  • SAP BTP: Deep dives into the Business Technology Platform and its transformative capabilities of SAP Hana with Vector Engine and Knowledge Graph
  • Next-Generation Talent: Insights into how SAP University Alliances is empowering the future of our ecosystem
  • SAP BTP Real-World Solutions: Practical implementations of SAP Integration Suite, CAP, FIORI, Printing solution, Identity Services, sand more
  • Freelance market barometer 2025

A special highlight was the Spanish final of the AUSIA Hackathon -  AUSAPE final,  where we witnessed incredible creativity and problem-solving. Congratulations to SDG Group for their winning solution combining AI, data modeling, and planning on SAP BTP, and to Brait Partners for their innovative electronic invoicing automation platform. Both teams proved that new technologies have real, tangible applications in today's business landscape.

The Power of Community: A New Milestone

Speaking of community strength, I'm thrilled to share some exciting news that perfectly exemplifies what we've built together: three new extraordinary members from our community have just joined the SAP Champions program! This recognition is a testament to the collaborative spirit, knowledge sharing, and genuine passion that defines our Barcelona and Spain SAP ecosystem. It's proof that when we come together, support each other, and actively contribute to the community, incredible things happen. These achievements don't belong to individuals alone — they're a reflection of the nurturing environment we've created through events like SIT Barcelona. Congratulations to our new Champions; you make us all proud! 🏆 @AAncos @DanielMateo @Lluis 


Gratitude to Those Who Made It Possible

None of this would have been possible without our amazing volunteering speakers who shared their expertise, experiences, and passion. Your willingness to prepare, present, and engage with attendees is what makes SIT Barcelona such a valuable learning experience. Thank you for your time, your knowledge, and your commitment to our community.
To our sponsors — thank you for believing in the power of community events. Your support enables us to create these spaces where innovation flourishes and connections are made. You're not just supporting an event; you're investing in the growth and development of the SAP ecosystem in Spain.

And I must give a huge, heartfelt thank you to the entire SIT Barcelona organizing team, Lluís, Mireia, Enric, Losel, Imma and Saul. Your dedication, countless hours of planning, problem-solving on the fly, and unwavering passion made this 9th edition possible. You are the backbone of this community, and working alongside each of you has been an absolute privilege💙

The Heart of It All: Community

What sets SAP Inside Track apart from other tech events is the genuine sense of community we've built together over these nine years. It's in the coffee conversations, the spontaneous debates about architecture patterns, the exchange of LinkedIn profiles, and yes, even in the collective patience when life happens (like dog medication time!).
I've seen friendships form, collaborations spark, and careers transform through the connections made at SIT Barcelona. Whether you're a first-time attendee or a veteran of all nine editions, everyone is welcomed with open arms into this wonderful ecosystem we've created together.

Looking Ahead

As we celebrate the success of our 9th edition, we're already excited about what's to come. The 10th anniversary of SIT Barcelona is on the horizon, and we have a feeling it's going to be something truly special.
To everyone who attended, spoke, sponsored, organized, or simply spread the word — thank you. You are the reason SAP Inside Track Barcelona exists and thrives. You are the community.
Until next year, keep innovating, keep sharing, and keep being awesome! 🚀

P.S. — If you missed this edition or want to be part of this amazing community, stay tuned for announcements about SIT Barcelona 2026. Trust me, you don't want to miss the 10th anniversary!
#SITBarcelona #SAPInsideTrack #SAPCommunity #SAP #SAPBTP #SAPDevelopers #CommunityEvents #BarcelonaTech #TechCommunity

entry.title: Re: Is the matrix relationship to the job relationship required?
entry.content: Hi Marion, yes, it’s perfectly fine to create position-level matrix relationships without mapping them to employee job relationships. Since your goal is to use them in workflow approver steps and not for employee profile visibility, the position-level setup alone will work. Just make sure the matrix relationships are correctly maintained at the position level so that the workflows can reference them properly.

entry.title: Introducing User-Defined Reports (UDR) in SAP Responsible Production and Design
entry.content:
Disclaimer: This blog post reflects the state of SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) as of November 25, 2025.

SAP Responsible Design and Production (RDP) released User-Defined Reports (UDR) this year, extending its reporting framework with a fully configurable, customer-driven approach developed to support customers with the ever-evolving and growing number of Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) regulations. With UDR, users can now create customized EPR reports for packaging based on their unique business and compliance needs.

UDR also enables SAP and in the near future, content partners, to offer templates for new EPR schemes that customers can copy into their own systems, to help them expand EPR reporting quickly. This new functionality aims to ease the burden of managing reporting obligations across multiple markets.

This blog post explains the background and motivation for this feature, provides a sneak peek into the key functionalities used to create country-specific EPR report categories, and highlights how this enhancement improves flexibility and extensibility for EPR data reporting.

Background

As EPR regulations continue to expand globally, businesses face increasing complexity in how they manage compliance. Regulations vary not only from country to country but often overlap or undergo changes over time, making it challenging for customers to keep up while relying on predefined reporting structures.

SAP RDP has long supported customers in meeting EPR requirements through SAP-provided report categories that are preconfigured to match the packaging obligations in countries such as Spain, Italy, and the UK. While these reports have served as a reliable foundation, there is a growing need for a more flexible and more nuanced reporting approach.

Companies increasingly require a way to:

  • Adapt quickly to new or changing legislation
  • Reuse rules and fee structures across similar reporting schemes or Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs)
  • Consolidate data from diverse sources
  • Customize reporting logic based on their specific business context

This is exactly why SAP introduced User-Defined Reports (UDR): to provide customers with an agile, scalable, and future-ready foundation for building report categories aligned with regulatory logic, business context, and compliance requirements.

Key Capabilities of UDR

User-Defined Reports bring together several powerful capabilities that allow customers to design report categories tailored to their specific regulatory and operational needs. 

1 Build the Structure of Your Report

Responsible Organizations

EPR schemes are managed by Producer Responsibility Organizations (PROs). Many countries operate with more than one PRO, each offering different fee structures or criteria. In Spain, for example, Ecoembes manages general packaging, while Ecovidrio is responsible for glass packaging. UDR allows users to:

  • Attach multiple PRO-specific fee tables to the same report category
  • Reuse the same report fractions and rules across PROs
  • Avoid creating separate report categories for each PRO (as long as their rules do not conflict)

This gives customers flexibility in markets where several PROs coexist.

Report Fractions

Report fractions are the foundational building blocks of a UDR report. They represent the categories into which packaging is classified according to national legislation or PRO requirements. Fractions can be created and named based on the exact fee structure of the country or PRO, ensuring a one-to-one alignment with how fees are calculated.

Report Fraction Groups

To support cleaner structuring and reporting layouts, fractions can be combined into report fraction groups. These groups help users organize related fractions (for example, grouping all paper-related fractions) and simplify both calculation and reporting outputs.

2 Control the Logic Behind Your Report

Filters for Included Packaging

Filters add a foundational layer of control by allowing users to exclude packaging that should not be part of a particular report or fee calculation. They can be applied at multiple levels within the report category setup and help ensure that only relevant data is included based on the requirements of each EPR scheme.

Together with calculation rules, filters help shape a reporting outcome that aligns with legislative and business requirements.

Calculation Rules

Report calculation rules form one of the most powerful elements of UDR.
They determine which packaging is included in a report and how quantities and fees are calculated, giving customers the flexibility to reflect the exact compliance logic required by each market. Because calculation rules can combine multiple conditions, attributes, and data sources, they enable users to shape reporting logic precisely around their business and regulatory needs, making this capability central to the flexibility that UDR offers.

Calculation rules come with an extensive rule library that offers a wide collection of rule examples, expressions and functions that can be leveraged to fit the users’ reporting requirements.

Logistic Processes

Logistic processes represent the specific movements of products or packaging that are relevant for a country’s EPR legislation, such as domestic sales, imports, exports, or other flows defined by the market. In UDR, users can select which logistic processes apply to their report category and combine them with filters or calculation rules. This allows the user to reflect only the movements that are obligated in that country, ensuring the report aligns with how packaging enters or leaves the market.

 

3 Capture Sustainability-Driven Criteria

Ecomodulation

Many EPR schemes increasingly use ecomodulation to reward sustainable packaging choices. UDR allows users to set ecomodulation criteria based on the relevant EPR scheme and incorporate them into calculation rules. This further enables fees to be calculated according to the required ecomodulation rules. To learn more about ecomodulation, visit the SAP RDP community page for a detailed blog on this topic, releasing soon.

Recyclability

UDR also integrates recyclability outcomes directly into reports. When setting up a report, recyclability guidelines can be selected and applied, to be used in calculation rules when needed. This allows recyclability insights to feed directly into the report structure, supporting countries where recyclability affects fees or criteria (such as the bonus/malus payments on EPR fees in France). Users can either upload date manually via Excel or integrate with a partner of their choice.

4 Test and Validate Your Setup

Test Configuration

With test configurations, users can simulate the reporting outcome for one to ten products. This enables quick validation of rule logic, filters, and fee calculations before generating the full report, ensuring accuracy and reducing iteration time.

5 Templates

Not all EPR schemes have the same level of complexity. To ease the effort in building highly detailed report categories using UDR, Templates have been introduced; preconfigured starter packs that provide the structure and logic needed to get started, which can be adapted to fit the user’s requirements.

Currently, SAP provides Templates for US-Colorado, US-Oregon, and Denmark, with more to follow. Keep an eye on the SAP RDP Roadmap for upcoming additions.

Customer Response & Early Results

Customers who tested UDR shared strong and practical feedback, including:

“Only 25% of time and effort is required for using UDR compared to manual efforts.” (from consumer products company)

“First we were skeptic, but now we like using UDR.” (from food processing company)

These early insights reflect the impact of a flexible, user-driven reporting approach. To see this in a real-world setting, please check out our recent webinar, Navigating EPR regulations in the United States: Act Now! where our customer shares their experience with UDR.

What’s Next

UDR was shaped with direct input from customers, and this collaboration will continue. As EPR regulations evolve, SAP will focus on enhancing UDR, improving the configuration experience, and supporting reporting needs across markets.

One of the planned enhancements is around AI-assisted features that could make it easier to create calculation rules logic and work more efficiently with UDR using natural language.

Where to Learn More and Act!

To further explore UDR, detailed documentation with practical examples and additional guidance on calculation rules  available. You can also access a guided, step-by-step walkthrough showing how to create a UDR here.  We will continue to publish updates there as UDR evolves.

For broader product information on SAP Responsible Design and Production, we recommend browsing the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release. 

To take the next step, you can request a demo or contact us for a consultation. For additional regulatory context and practical guidance, you may also want to download our white paper on managing EPR regulations and plastic taxes.

entry.title: Re: How to Call RAP Actions with Table Types from a List Report
entry.content:
@akhileshvatupalli123464 

My example already requires frontend code. If you are asking about "opening a popup" without the need to define fragments etc., yes, it is possible with the EditFlow's invokeAction method. Instead of using ContextBinding's execute method, invokeAction integrates with the Extension API and opens a popup if parameters are required for the action.

An alternative would be to define an action that takes a single entity and returns a single result, and set the invocation grouping to "change set". This way, all the selected rows will be passed to the event handler and can be processed in one go. 

Action Definition

action actionname parameter zabs_input result [1] zabs_output;

Annotation

 @UI.lineItem: [
  {
    label: 'Activate',
    dataAction: 'myAction',
    invocationGrouping: #CHANGE_SET,
    type: #FOR_ACTION,
    position: 1 
  }
]
